title: 75 Classy Ways to Tell Off Someone in Your Life

steps.title: Maintain a professional demeanor when telling someone off at work.
steps.content: Maintain a professional demeanor when telling someone off at work. steps.title: Get a little space without completely ruining your relationships.
steps.content: Get a little space without completely ruining your relationships. Family members can be so aggravating, but they‚Äôre still family. ‚ÄúGiving yourself the time and space to calm down and analyze your immediate emotional reaction, as well as considering the situation from their point of view, will allow you to approach the conflict from a more logical, productive standpoint at a later time,‚Äù advises Board-certified psychiatrist Kirsten Thompson. steps.title: Communicate your dissatisfaction with a carefully worded email.
steps.content: Communicate your dissatisfaction with a carefully worded email. Thompson explains, ‚ÄúIt is best to practice respect and empathy when handling conflict with anyone.‚Äù This is especially true when you‚Äôre communicating by email, when it‚Äôs easy to misunderstand someone‚Äôs meaning. Should you need further clarification, please don‚Äôt hesitate to contact me. Awaiting your reply. Just following up on my email below. Let me know if I should talk to someone else on this. steps.title: Stay calm and take a minute to avoid acting in anger.
steps.content: Stay calm and take a minute to avoid acting in anger. Professional life coach Amber Rosenberg suggests, ‚ÄúGive it a day or two and see. Check in with yourself. See how you're feeling‚Ä¶If it still bothers you, it's a sign that your relationship will be served well by addressing it.‚Äù Above all, try to control your temper and think before you speak. Staying calm helps you manage your own stress levels, take control of your behavior, and pay attention to what you‚Äôre really feeling. Be aware of your nonverbal communication when working to resolve a conflict . Rolling your eyes or making an annoyed face can seem dismissive or confrontational.

steps.title: Define and communicate the most important parts of the conflict.
steps.content: Define and communicate the most important parts of the conflict. ‚ÄúI'm not saying you bring up every little thing that bothers you, because there's going to probably be many, but you pick and choose what's most important to you,‚Äù advises Rosenberg. Try to pinpoint where the real problem is and then communicate it to the other person in a clear, specific, and nonthreatening way. Marriage and family therapist Jessica George suggests, ‚ÄúTell them how you feel, but avoid pointing your fingers at them.‚Äù She adds, ‚ÄúUse ‚ÄòI‚Äô statements, but be sure to let them know that this will not be tolerated. This is where you can assert very strong boundaries.‚Äù

steps.title: Listen to the other person and try to understand what they say.
steps.content: Listen to the other person and try to understand what they say. George explains that it‚Äôs important for each person to take a turn speaking while the other person focuses on absorbing what they‚Äôre saying. Then, the listener repeats back what the speaker said. This slows the conversation down, which makes it easier to work toward a resolution. Ask the other person to tell you what they think the problem is. Encourage them to be as open and honest as possible. Clearly communicate your willingness to solve the issue so they‚Äôre comfortable letting you know what‚Äôs really bothering them. When they speak, make sure you‚Äôre using active listening skills to really hear and understand what they‚Äôre saying.

steps.title: Take steps to avoid conflict in the future.
steps.content: Take steps to avoid conflict in the future. It may not be possible to completely avoid conflict in your relationships, but you can take steps to minimize the fallout. According to Rosenberg, ‚Äú[Conflict is] really a natural part of relationships, and it will serve you and the other person in the relationship if you address it head-on.‚Äù Licensed professional counselor William Schroeder suggests, ‚ÄúTry to engage someone and just set a framework for what you‚Äôd like to change: When X happened, I felt Y, and I wanted Z.‚Äù He adds that you should always start from a place of empathy and compassion. You may not be able to change their mind, but empathy goes a long way to resolving conflict.
